table.name: mem
table.column: This refers to the sound, and not to any letter or glyph.

table.name: mem
table.column: This word can be used when talking about phases of a moon, for example, but it's not used to refer to living things (people, animals, plants) except idiomatically. To say to someone {bItab:sen@@bI-:v, tab:v} is to say "you are not applying yourself fully to the task at hand." It would be extremely unlikely to hear a Klingon say {jItab:sen@@jI-:v, tab:v} "I wane" or {matab:sen@@ma-:v, tab:v} "we wane".[1]
Someone who is multitasking on a computer (and thus not paying their full attention to the task at hand) has many "tab"s open.

table.name: mem
table.column: This word is not used to refer to living things, except idiomatically. It's not unheard of to say {bItabHa':sen@@bI-:v, tabHa':v} to a lazy worker or trainee who is finally up to speed, but it's not common. But this would never be said to someone who's been training or practicing or working diligently all along.[1]

table.name: mem
mem
table.column: We will meet in the cocktail lounge.

table.name: mem
table.column:
This would be used if something flipped all the way over on its own accord or seemingly on its own accord (even if there is a known cause). If it was flipped over by something else, see {yoymoH:v}. If it was tipped over but not completely flipped, see {qaw':v}.
If one flipped over in bed, one would normally say {jItach:sen@@jI-:v, tach:v}. One could say {jItach'eghmoH:sen@@jI-:v, tach:v, -'egh:v, -moH:v} if there were a particular struggle or effort involved.
One is more likely to use {tachmoH:v@@tach:v, -moH:v} than {yoymoH:v:nolink} when moving someone from a prone to a supine position (or vice versa). One is more likely to use {yoymoH:v:nolink} than {tachmoH:v:nolink} when flipping hamburgers or pancakes. Either would be fine for flipping over cards, with {yoymoH:v:nolink} implying a quicker or crisper action.

table.name: mem
table.column: This word also has the idiomatic sense of "don't move!" when given as a command, either as {yItaD:sen@@yI-:v, taD:v} (spoken to one person) or {petaD:sen@@pe-:v, taD:v} (spoken to a group of people).[2; 3] To order someone to literally freeze, the suffixes {-'egh:v} and {-moH:v} would be used: {yItaD'eghmoH:sen@@yI-:v, taD:v, -'egh:v, -moH:v} "Freeze yourself!" ("Cause yourself to be frozen!")[3]

table.name: mem
table.column: The name of an ice-covered colony planet in the Klingon Empire. Its name literally means "frozen" ({taD:v}).

table.name: mem
table.column:
The subject of this verb is the person or thing starting the process, and the object is the process. For example: {Qu' DataghDI' 'aqtu' mellota' je tIqaw.:sen}[2]
If the starter of the process is unknown, unclear, or indefinite, the process becomes the subject of the verb (in which case it takes no object): {taghbej mu'qaD veS.:sen}[3]
Instead of using the verb {tagh:v:nolink}, consider using the verb suffix {-choH:v:suff}. For example, a student who is a beginner might be described as a {ghojchoHwI'} (one who is beginning to learn) or said to be {ghojchoH} (beginning to learn).

table.name: mem
table.column: ▶ {tagha' pawpu' meb 'ach pumDI' Heghpu' qagh.:sen:nolink} "The guest finally arrived, but by then the gagh had died."[1]

table.name: mem
table.column: This was defined as "continue, go on, survive" in {TKDA:src} and as "survive" in {KGT:src}.

table.name: mem
table.column: This refers to a ship in space which has rotated its nose downwards. A rotation through a negative angle of 90 degrees would mean that the ship's nose was pointed straight down relative to its previous orientation.[2]
The mailing list message refers to an explanation given at SerenityCon.

table.name: mem
table.column: To be or not to be.
These lines have been translated from the original Klingon by Nick Nicholas and Andrew Strader.

table.name: mem
table.column: Maltz felt sure that there is a connection between this expletive and the expression {bItaHrup'a'?:sen}, but he could not explain what it was.[3]
This is just described as an epithet in {TKD:src}. Its description as a "classical insult" comes from {CK:src}.

table.name: mem
mem
table.column: extra blade on a d'k tahg

table.name: mem
table.column: Angles are measured in {lawrI':n} (or {law:n} in more ancient times or in traditional documents).[2]

table.name: mem
table.column: Presumably, there is a place called {talar:n:place,fic,nolink}.

table.name: mem
table.column: This is the metallic chemical element with the symbol Co and atomic number 27.

table.name: mem
table.column: ▶ {cha'pujqutmey chIm lutamlu'.:sen@@cha'pujqut:n, -mey:n, chIm:v, lu-:v, tam:v:2, -lu':v} "Drained dilithium crystals are replaced."[2]

table.name: mem
table.column: This appeared in {STC 104:src} as {DIvI' tamey ngo':n:nolink} "Federation Archives". A single archive record would be {ta ngo':n:nolink}.

table.name: mem
table.column:
For "light" in the sense of "brightness", for example someone's eyes being "sensitive to light", consider {wovtaHghach:n@@wov:v, -taH:v, -ghach:v} instead.[1]
A dim light would be {tamghay wovHa':n@@tamghay:n, wov:v, -Ha':v} (whereas {tamghay Hurgh:n@@tamghay:n, Hurgh:v} sounds odd).[2]
This is a reference to Tom G. Smith of Industrial Light & Magic, who oversaw visual effects production for {Star Trek II:src} and {Star Trek III:src}.

table.name: mem
table.column: A reference to Tom Lehrer, who performed the song "The Elements" about the chemical elements.

table.name: mem
table.column: This word does not appear in canon, but is an obvious construction based on {tamlerQeD:n:nolink}.

table.name: mem
table.column: This word was used in {ghIlghameS:n:nolink}, where {QI'tu' tangqa':n:nolink} refers to the Bull of Heaven.
The Lakota or Sioux word for "buffalo" is "tatanka".

table.name: mem
table.column:
A reference to the sound made.
The English translation of the sentence from {Star Trek Constellations:src} does not appear in the book, but in the author's annotations which was a separate document. The Klingon sentence was printed with a typo in the book, a space after {qIrq:n:name}. It's clear that {-'e':n:suff} was intended since the English translation fronts "Kirk": "Kirk I want alive" (as opposed to "I want Kirk alive").

▶ {yIntaH qIrq'e' vIneH. DaSwIj bIngDaq latlhpu' vItap.:sen@@yIn:v, -taH:v, qIrq:n:name, -'e':n, vI-:v, neH:v, DaS:n, -wIj:n, bIng:n, -Daq:n, latlh:n, -pu':n, vI-:v, tap:v} "Kirk I want alive. The rest I will grind beneath my boot."[2]

table.name: mem
table.column: This is a fruit similar to a cherry. When clarification is needed, for the Earth fruit, precede with {tera':n}.
Getting three cherries in a slot machine means hitting the "jackpot".

table.name: mem
table.column:
The residents of this region greatly outnumber the residents of {Qotmagh Sep:n}.
This dialect is sort of half-way between the standard dialect and the {Qotmagh Sep:n} dialect. Speakers replace {b:sen:nolink} with {mb:sen:nolink} and {D:sen:nolink} with {ND:sen:nolink}.[1, p.22]

This word appears only in the body of {KGT:src} on p.22 and not in the glossary. It appears as {taq'ev:n:nolink} and not as {taq'ev Sep:n:nolink}, but it is implied that this is the name of a region (see {Sep:n}).

table.name: mem
table.column: This means "weird" as in bizarre, unnatural, maybe creepy.[2]
This is missing from the E-K side of {TKD:src}.

table.name: mem
table.column: This is a reference to a line from the movie "Dr. Strangelove" ({taQ:v}, {bang:n}): "A big plane like a '52... varrrooom! Its jet exhaust... frying chickens in the barnyard!"

table.name: mem
table.column: This is just a Federation Standard word with Klingon pronunciation.

table.name: mem
table.column: This is a kind of animal somewhat resembling a dog. It is popular as a pet, but its heart is also considered a delicacy.[2]

table.name: mem
table.column: targhlIj yab tIn law' no'lI' Hoch yabDu' tIn puS!
Your targ has a bigger brain than all your ancestors put together!

table.name: mem
table.column: This is one of several crab-like animals found on {Qo'noS:n}.

table.name: mem
table.column:
This is the metallic chemical element with the symbol W and atomic number 74.
The fact that it seems to contain the word {tar:n} "poison" might just be a coincidence.[1]
{targh:n} "wolf" + {'o'nI':n} "foam". The word "wolfram" derives from the Latin "lupi spuma" meaning "wolf's froth".

table.name: mem
table.column:
This is the metallic chemical element with the symbol U and atomic number 92.
The fact that this looks like {tar:n} "poison" and {ngeb:v} "fake" might just be a coincidence.[1]
Pitchblende is an ore of uranium. Another word for pitch is "tar", and (zinc) blende is also referred to as "false galena" ({ngeb:v}).
▶ {woj tlhuD tarngeb:sen@@woj:n, tlhuD:v, tarngeb:n} "uranium is radioactive"[1]

table.name: mem
table.column: The Tasman Sea separates Australia from New Zealand, and is colloquially called "the Ditch".

table.name: mem
table.column: This verb means to return something somewhere, for example a weapon to the weapons rack. To express the concept of returning to a place, use {chegh:v}.[1]
This was defined as "return" with an explanation of how it differs from {chegh:v:nolink}. The definition "return (something)" comes from the KLI new words list.
▶ {raSDaq jengva' vItatlh.:sen:nolink} "I return the plate to the table."[1]

table.name: mem
table.column: Though not common, the verb {tatlh:v} can be used with the suffix {-'egh:v} to convey a meaning similar to {chegh:v}. The {tatlh'egh:v:nolink} form seems to suggest that the doer of the action is forcing himself/herself to do something, perhaps because it is difficult or not desirable.
▶ {pa'Daq jItatlh'egh.:sen:nolink} "I return to the room." The implication here is that it is difficult or not desirable to return to the room.[1]

table.name: mem
table.column: This is what someone might do to wake somebody up, or what one might do to a drink or a limb. What freezing temperatures may do to someone is {jelmoH:v@@jel:v, -moH:v}, not {tav:v:nolink}.

table.name: mem
table.column: This slang expression literally means "merely shake". If the context is clear that "shake" in the literal sense is not what is meant, {tav:v} alone can be used.[1]

table.name: mem
table.column: This is the physical counterpart of a {He:n}, something which one can see and walk on.

A reference to the Tao (道), obviously.
Marc Okrand noted that he can't answer yet the question of whether an airlane (a fixed pathway in the air where airplanes are supposed to go) is a {taw:n:nolink} or a {He:n:nolink}.

table.name: mem
table.column: Klingon counterpart (more or less) of the "best man" at a wedding. This is normally translated as "sword-bearer", but etymologically that's not quite right. It's a frozen and somewhat modified form of an old word which was apparently something like {taywI'yan:n:nolink}, having something to do with ceremony or ritual {tay:n:2} and sword {yan:n}, but the details of the old grammatical construction are unknown.[1]

table.name: mem
table.column: To be even more emphatic, one could say {tawleHnu' pogh:n@@tawleHnu':n, pogh:n}.

Maltz didn't know how gloves are involved or if there is a word which just happens to be a homophone of {pogh:n} that he didn't remember.
This refers to the expression "going to hell ({Hel:sen:nolink}) in a hand ({ghop:n}) basket ({'unwat:n})".

table.name: mem
table.column: This word might be used to refer to a fossil embedded into a stone. It is not used when referring to foreheads.

table.name: mem
table.column: Klingons apparently consider a people to be civilized if they have rituals (see {tay:n:2}).

table.name: mem
table.column: This is something that "tie"s a community together. Also, the procedure of putting on a neck"tie" is a kind of ritual.

table.name: mem
table.column: From lowest to highest, these ranks are: {tay:n:3,nolink}, {Sutay:n}, {veStay:n}, {Santay:n}, {'Iptay:n}.
This is a rank from John M. Ford's 1984 novel "The Final Reflection". These ranks are used by many Klingon fan clubs, despite not appearing in canon (i.e., in any TV episode or movie).

table.name: mem
table.column: section of a book or play separate from main portion of the work

This refers to a section of a book or play or the like that is separate from the main portion of the work. It's seldom used without {bI'reS:n} or {bertlham:n}, except when already established by prior context. Despite its description, {taymey:n} is not used for the appendix of a work (for which see {HommaH:n}). A {taymey:n:nolink} contextualizes the main work, whereas an appendix is considered supplemental. This word may be a remnant of the way stories used to be told orally, since they'd begin and end with some sort of ritual ({tay:n:2}), the details of which are lost. Even though {taymey:n:nolink} appears to end with the plural suffix {-mey:n}, it is a frozen form and is considered singular. Thus, it's possible to say {taymeymey:n@@taymey:n, -mey:n} should the need arise.[1]

table.name: mem
table.column: This word seems to be composed of {tay:n:2} or {tay:v} and {qeq:n} or {qeq:v}. Perhaps this is an indication of what Klingons consider important to a civilisation.

table.name: mem
table.column: This verb is also used to specify membership in a Klingon House (see explanation under {tuq:n}).

table.name: mem
table.column: A planet in the Klingon Empire, where the induction into the Order of the Bat'leth takes place.[2]

table.name: mem
table.column: This was defined as "accomplishment" in {TKD:src}, but as "deed, accomplishment" in {KGT:src}.

table.name: mem
table.column: This is short for {ta' tlhIngan Hol:n}.

table.name: mem
table.column: This is the standard dialect of Klingon. It is also called {ta' Hol:n} for short.

table.name: mem
table.column: This verb may be used for filling a hole ({QemjIq:n}), but not for merely stopping up an opening ({qung:n}), which would be {qorgh:v}.[2]

table.name: mem
table.column: In {TOS - Elaan of Troyius:src}, Spock says that the Klingons claim jurisdiction over {telun Hovtay':n}. As a number of other words in {TKD:src} also come from this episode, it's likely that {teblaw':n:nolink} was intended to translate "jurisdiction" in this abstract sense.

table.name: mem
table.column: food server in a Dok'e (fast-food restaurant)

table.name: mem
table.column: The computer programming control flow concepts "if" and "while" were translated as {teHchugh:sen:nolink} and {teHtaHvIS:sen:nolink}, respectively, in Klingon Blockly. Setting a boolean variable to "true" was translated as {teHmoH:sen:nolink}, while setting one to "false" was translated as {teHbe'moH:sen:nolink}.[4]

table.name: mem
table.column: Generally, for every {QeD:n} there is a corresponding {tej:n:nolink}.[2]

table.name: mem
table.column:
This is missing from the E-K side of {TKD:src}.
This word takes the suffix {-Du':n:suff} when it refers to a body part, and {-mey:n:suff} otherwise. This is known from {telmey ghajbogh muD Duj:n:nolink} "winged aircraft" from the {Smithsonian GO FLIGHT app:src}.

table.name: mem
table.column: This appears to violate the rule in {TKD:src} that the first noun in a noun-noun construction cannot take a type 5 noun suffix. There are several possible ways to explain this: there may be an exception for "list items", this is a "clipped" form and something was dropped (e.g., {tu'lu'bogh:sen:nolink}), or {telDaq:n:nolink} is a compound of {tel:n} and {Daq:n} meaning "wing-location".

table.name: mem
table.column: This is the home planet of a founding member of the United Federation of Planets ({yuQjIjDIvI':n}).

table.name: mem
table.column: This star system is located near the Federation-Klingon border, and contains the two planets {Doy'yuS:n} and {'elaS:n}.

table.name: mem
table.column: Backwards of {'aylet:sen:nolink} "islet". The islets of Langerhans, or pancreatic islets, are clusters of cells within the pancreas.

table.name: mem
table.column: This means "contradict, disavow, claim as false" and the like. It does not mean "refuse, reject, turn down, don't permit".[2]

table.name: mem
table.column: The child of a {tennuS:n:nolink} is a {tey':n:1}.
This is a reference to "Uncle Tonoose" from the Danny Thomas Show.

table.name: mem
table.column: This is used only for numbered pages in a book or something similar.

table.name: mem
mem
table.column: In the {BoP:src} poster, this is a type of crane.

table.name: mem
table.column: For the removal of something from the interior, consider {lel:v}.

table.name: mem
table.column:
This is the name of the Human Homeworld. For "earth" in the sense of "dirt", see {lam:n}.
Earth is a major planet in the Federation ({DIvI':n}) and the third planet in the {Sol:n} star system. The continents of Earth are: ▶ {'amerI'qa' tIng chan tIng:n} "South America" ▶ {'amerI'qa' 'ev chan 'ev:n} "North America" ▶ {'antartIq:n} "Antarctica" ▶ {'aSralya':n} "Australia" ▶ {'aSya':n} "Asia" ▶ {'avrI'qa':n} "Africa" ▶ {'ewrop:n} "Europe"

table.name: mem
table.column:
There is an idiom, {Hoj; tera'ngan rur@@Hoj:v, tera'ngan:n, rur:v}.
Note that a human ({Human:n}) is a member of the major indigenous language-capable species of Earth ({tera':n:place}), whereas Terran ({tera'ngan:n:nolink}) refers to any inhabitant of the planet.

table.name: mem
table.column: Maltz says Klingons don't get colds (though, despite what he says, Klingons are not immune from other, somewhat similar afflictions). Another way to refer to this Earth disease, generally unsympathetically, is {tera' rop bIr:n}, which is, of course, a misguided translation.

table.name: mem
table.column: If the context is clear, this may be shortened to {nagh DIr charwI':n:nolink}.

table.name: mem
table.column: This is what Klingons would call the Terran fruit.

table.name: mem
table.column: This is what Klingons would call the Terran fruit.

table.name: mem
table.column: The {tera':n:place} may be dropped if the context is clear. This literally means "gelatinous orange".

table.name: mem
table.column: The {tera':n:place} may be dropped if the context is clear. This literally means "orange slime".

table.name: mem
table.column: This is what Klingons would call the Terran fruit.

table.name: mem
table.column: This is what Klingons would call the Terran fruit.

table.name: mem
table.column:
This term is used in the invitation to {Star Trek The Exhibition:src}. The invitation reads: ▶ {tera' poH jaj wa', jar wa', jaj loSDIch, DIS wa'-Hut-Hut-chorgh. HovpoHvetlh latlh nab yIHutlh.:sen:nolink} "Save this Stardate: Sunday, January 4, 1998".[1]
Based on the information on the invitation, when telling an Earth date: ▶ the days of the week are mapped to their Klingon analogues (see under {Hogh:n}); ▶ {jar:n} followed by a number labels the month, starting with January, {jar wa':n:nolink}; ▶ the day of the month is given as an ordinal, {jaj loSDIch:n:nolink} "the fourth day"; ▶ the year is specified by giving its digits after the word {DIS:n:2}.[1]
The Terran months are: ▶ {jar wa':n:nolink} "January" ▶ {jar cha':n:nolink} "February" ▶ {jar wej:n:nolink} "March" ▶ {jar loS:n:nolink} "April" ▶ {jar vagh:n:nolink} "May" ▶ {jar jav:n:nolink} "June" ▶ {jar Soch:n:nolink} "July" ▶ {jar chorgh:n:nolink} "August" ▶ {jar Hut:n:nolink} "September" ▶ {jar wa'maH:n:nolink} "October" ▶ {jar wa'maH wa':n:nolink} "November" ▶ {jar wa'maH cha':n:nolink} "December"
Terran date, Terran time, January, February, March, April, May, June, July, August, September, October, November, December

table.name: mem
table.column: This is the Klingon way to refer to the Terran fruit. The {tera':n} is optional.[1]

table.name: mem
table.column: Maltz says Klingons don't get colds (though, despite what he says, Klingons are not immune from other, somewhat similar afflictions). Another way to refer to this Earth disease, generally unsympathetically, is {tera' rop bIr:n}, which is, of course, a misguided translation.

table.name: mem
table.column: This is what Klingons would call the Terran fungus.

table.name: mem
table.column: This refers to the Terran plant.

table.name: mem
table.column: This refers to the organ of hearing inside the head, while {qogh:n:2,body} refers to the external flap of skin, cartilage, etc.

table.name: mem
table.column: This was not given an English definition, but was described as the device Uhura wears (which contrasts with a {DannI':n:nolink} in not covering both ears).

table.name: mem
table.column: This refers to a piece used in a game (such as Scrabble) or a puzzle.

table.name: mem
table.column: The object is the thing which is melted.

table.name: mem
table.column: This refers to any sort of artificial coating, not just enamel. It does not apply to teeth.

table.name: mem
table.column: This word can be used for anything rolled up like a scroll, and has also commonly come to denote any kind of list, while {Qumran:n} refers to a more ceremonial kind of scroll.[3]

The Klingon phrase as printed on the {BoP:src} poster contains typos.
This word was used for the "list" variable type in Klingon Blockly.[4]

table.name: mem
table.column: roll (down a hill like a log)
Though this verb is related to the noun {tetlh:n}, it is not used for scrolls (unless a scroll happens to be rolling down a hill).

table.name: mem
table.column: Aside from its literal meaning, this can also be used for the sense of being close or not having wiggle room or leeway in a situation. See {tey:v:2}.[2]

table.name: mem
table.column: be uncomfortable, be close, not have wiggle room or leeway
▶ {tey yay:sen:@@tey:v:2, yay:n:2h} (this describes something which was just barely a victory or a last-minute victory, or something like that)

table.name: mem
table.column: be comfortable, be not close, have wiggle room or leeway
▶ {teybe' yay:sen@@teybe':v, yay:n:2h} "the victory didn't scrape", "the victory was comfortable"

table.name: mem
table.column: This means "file" in the sense of a nail file and the like, not a data file (for which see {ta:n}).
This is defined as "file" in {KGT:src}. The "tool" part was added for clarification.

table.name: mem
table.column: This refers to any large writing surface which can be erased and reused.[1]
An "eraser" for such a board would presumably be a {teywI':n}.

table.name: mem
table.column: This word refers to one's mother's sister's child or one's father's brother's child (i.e., "parallel cousins").

table.name: mem
table.column: For a man, this word refers to the child of his brother. For a woman, it refers to the child of her sister.

table.name: mem
table.column: A female {tey':n:0}, that is, a cousin who is one's mother's sister's child or one's father's brother's child, or a niece in the sense of a man's brother's daughter or a woman's sister's daughter.

table.name: mem
table.column: A male {tey':n:0}, that is, a cousin who is one's mother's sister's son or one's father's brother's son, or nephew in the sense of a man's brother's son or a woman's sister's son.

table.name: mem
table.column: ▶ {tlhIngan tIgh DaHaDrup'a'?} (one of several inscriptions used by MO when signing books or photos) ▶ {tlhIngan tIgh - SuvwI' DevmeH paq@@tlhIngan:n, tIgh:n, SuvwI':n, DevmeH paq:n} "The Klingon Way - A Warrior's Guide"[2]

table.name: mem
table.column: There is an idiom {Dogh; tIghla' rur:sen@@Dogh:v, tIghla':n, rur:v}.[1, p.127]

table.name: mem
table.column: This word refers to any energy beam. It is an extension of the traditional meaning of {tIH:n:2} (spear shaft) to modern weaponry.[2, p.65]

table.name: mem
table.column: This word has been adapted for modern weaponry; see {tIH:n:1} (energy beam). It's also used to talk about railroads, for which see {tIHmey:n}.

table.name: mem
table.column: It's not clear whether a singular {tIH:n:nolink} would refer to a single rail (i.e., half a track), a single section of track, or something else.

table.name: mem
table.column: ▶ {nuqDaq lupwI' mIr vItIj?@@nuqDaq:ques, lupwI' mIr:n, vI-:v, tIj:v} "Where is the train station?"[2]

table.name: mem
table.column: A "tin" is a box used to hold "match"es.

table.name: mem
table.column: area southwestward, area towards the southwest
This is approximately 220 degrees on a Terran compass, if north is 0 and degrees are counted clockwise.

table.name: mem
table.column: all around, all over the place
▶ {tIngvo' 'evDaq chanDaq jIlengpu'.:sen:nolink} "I've traveled all over the place."[1]

table.name: mem
table.column: area westward, area towards the west

This is the midway point between the cardinal directions {tIng:n} and {'ev:n}. It is also referred to as {'ev tIng:n:nolink} with about the same frequency.[1] It is 270 degrees on a Terran compass, if north is 0 and degrees are counted clockwise.

table.name: mem
table.column: This is a type of {HurDagh:n}. It is larger than the {Supghew:n} and the {leSpal:n}.

table.name: mem
table.column: "Tippecanoe and Tyler Too". Ash Tyler is a character in {Star Trek Discovery:src}.

table.name: mem
table.column: The verb used for "beat" (as in a heartbeat) is {joq:v}.
Tick tock, the sound of a heart beat. The heart is also colloquially called the "ticker".

table.name: mem
table.column: Real power is in the heart.

table.name: mem
table.column: This refers to a type of Terran food.

table.name: mem
table.column: Hit them hard and hit them fast.

table.name: mem
table.column: An edged weapon, similar to an Earth longsword.

table.name: mem
table.column: The tknag is a dangerous carnivore native to the Klingon planet Taganika.[2]

table.name: mem
table.column: As a food item, they are always referred to in the plural.

table.name: mem
table.column:
T'Kuvma was proclaimed to be "T'Kuvma the Unforgettable" ({tIquvma lIjlaHbe'bogh vay':sen:nolink}) by his followers, in an allusion to Kahless the Unforgettable (see {qeylIS'e' lIjlaHbe'bogh vay':n:name}).
His supporters include {lIr'el:n:name} and {voq:n:name}. His flagship is a sarcophagus ship covered in coffins (see {nebeylI':n}, {nev'aQ:n}, {pel'aQ:n:2}).

table.name: mem
table.column: I must show you my heart.

table.name: mem
table.column: This verb is also used for equilateral triangles (see {ra'Duch tIQ:n}).

table.name: mem
table.column: This refers to the physical piece of dried bread, and not to the exclamations made while drinking.

table.name: mem
table.column: be arranged in a stack, be superimposed
"Superimpose A and B" is {A B je tIrmoHchu':sen:nolink}. One way to say "superimpose A on(to) B" is {B-Daq A lanchu':sen:nolink} (see {lan:v}).

"Tier".
In the printed booklet for {qep'a' 26 (2019):src}, there was a typo and {lanchu':sen:nolink} was incorrectly written as {lalchu':sen:nolink}.

table.name: mem
table.column:
For verbs used to express the enjoyment of food or music among Klingons, see {DuQ:v:2} and {'ey:v}.[2]
Klingons do not typically speak about music in terms of enjoyment, but rather in terms of what it does to the listener. For example, music might be said to {jaqmoH:v}, {SeymoH:v}, {tungHa':v}, or {pIlmoH:v}.[2]
This verb can be used reflexively to mean "enjoy oneself", "have a good time".[3; 4]
The {msn:src} example had a typo: {ghoHtah:sen:nolink} instead of {ghoHtaH:sen:nolink}.

▶ {petIv'egh. qara'qu'.:sen@@pe-:v, tIv:v, -'egh:v, qa-:v, ra':v:1, -qu':v} "Enjoy yourselves. That's an order."[3] ▶ {qep'a' wejDIchDaq jatlhtaH tlhIngan Hol HaDwI'pu'. ghoHtaH je. tIv'eghtaH je. vaj SuquvmoH.:sen:nolink}[4] ▶ {SutIv'egh'a'?:sen@@Su-:v, tIv:v, -'egh:v, -'a':v} "You will enjoy yourselves?"[5]
[1] {TKD:src}, [2] {KGT:src}, [3] {Star Trek V:src}, [4] {msn 1996.11.10:src}, [5] {"A Klingon Christmas Carol" trailer:src}

table.name: mem
table.column: It is stated that this cannot take an object.
[1] {Saarbrücken qepHom'a' 2017:src}, [2] {DSC - The Butcher's Knife Cares Not for the Lamb's Cry:src}

table.name: mem
table.column: The request was specifically for a word applicable to hair, though the given word seems more general.

table.name: mem
table.column: Unlike {rach:v}, this verb is not typically applied to beings, and it suggests only restoration to a previous state (and not necessarily improvement).[2]

table.name: mem
table.column: There is an idiom, {bIt; tI'qa' vIghro' rur@@bIt:v, tI'qa' vIghro':n, rur:v}.
{bIt:v:nolink} is actually written incorrectly as {tIb:v:nolink} on {KGT p.132:src}, in the statement of the idiom.

table.name: mem
table.column: This is the name of the planet.

table.name: mem
table.column: This was confirmed during the Q & A session.

table.name: mem
table.column: This verb can be used for proving one's honor ({quv tob:sen@@quv:n, tob:v}). See {Hay':v}.

In the {TKD:src} word list, this was defined as just "prove". In the {TKDA:src} word list, this was clarified to "test conclusively, prove".
This word appears in a deleted line from {Star Trek V:src}: {logh veQDaq bachchugh, yoH 'e' toblaHbe' SuvwI'.@@logh:n, veQ:n, -Daq:n, bach:v, -chugh:v, yoH:v, 'e':n, tob:v, -laH:v, -be':v, SuvwI':n} "Shooting space garbage is no test of a warrior's mettle." This line was changed to {vaj toDuj Daj ngeHbej DI vI'.:sen} (while maintaining the original English subtitle) in the process of editing.

▶ {SIQwI' lu'oy'moHmeH juppu'Daj 'oy'naQmey lo' chaH. SuvwI' qa' patlh veb chavlaHmeH tlhIngan lo'chu' chaH. toDujDaj toblu'.:sen:nolink} "The Painstik is employed by friends of the recipent who use the devices to inflict pain in a manner which will allow the Klingon to attain a higher state of spirituality as a warrior, proving his mettle."[3]

table.name: mem
table.column: This is normally used with the verb {chup:v} and sometimes {much:v:1}. It's not normally used with {nob:v}. A slang term for the verb "bribe" is {pupqa':v}.[1]
To slang, to "grease someone's palm" ({toch:n}) is to offer a bribe. ({Damu':n} "crease" sounds close to "grease".)

table.name: mem
table.column: For courage of a surprising or unexpected kind, see {qajunpaQ:n}.
In the {Smithsonian GO FLIGHT app:src}, the name of the airplane "Spirit of St. Louis" was translated as "St. Louis {toDuj:sen:nolink}".

table.name: mem
table.column: A beard is a symbol of courage.

table.name: mem
table.column: This is roughly like the English "Aha!" ({TKD 5.5:src})

table.name: mem
table.column: If the deception involves honor or social status, see {Qaq:v}.

table.name: mem
table.column: This was given in the plural. A single holodeck adventure might possibly be a {tojbogh pa' tuH:n@@tojbogh pa':n, tuH:n}, but it's not clear whether Klingons think of one holodeck adventure as one maneuver or several.

table.name: mem
table.column: go through, pass through, pass among
This is used for traveling through an undifferentiated mass or collection of objects using the space between them (a forest, a crowd, water, soil, space).

table.name: mem
table.column: This can be used for a head movement.
It is explicitly stated that this verb is intransitive, and that {tommoH:v@@tom:v, -moH:v} is used for the subject tilting the object.

table.name: mem
table.column:
This refers to a single technique executed in a fight or, by extension, a single maneuver played in a game.[3]
It is also used to name martial arts stances. To command someone to strike a stance or pose, the verb {much:v:3} is used. The word {tonSaw':n:nolink} may be left out of the name if the context is clear.[4]
To translate "The Final Reflection", where "reflection" is a maneuver in a game (see {tlhInja:n}), Maltz suggested {tonSaw' Qav:n:nolink} or {neSlo' tonSaw' Qav:n:nolink}.[3]
move, maneuver, manoeuvre, manoeuver, stance, pose

table.name: mem
table.column: Tom Terrific is a cartoon character who wears a funnel-shaped "thinking cap".

table.name: mem
table.column: This is a rare mineral which is mined.

table.name: mem
table.column: There is an idiom, {tlhIb; toppa' rur}.

table.name: mem
table.column: Its small eggs are eaten whole, shell and all, by the handful.[1, p.88]
The misspelling "Tokvarian" appears in the K-E word list. The spelling is correct in the E-K word list and on {KGT p.88:src}.

table.name: mem
table.column:
This refers to a tool or device, and not a postage stamp (for which see {HIjmeH chaw':n}).
To use such a stamp, one must first ink it up ({laS:v}) with an ink pad ({rItlh 'echlet:n}), then slam it down ({Dut:v:1}). The resulting image is called a {yang:n}.
▶ {toqwIn vIDut@@toqwIn:n, vI-:v, Dut:v:1} "I slam down the stamp."

table.name: mem
table.column: type of animal, similar to Terran bird of prey

table.name: mem
table.column: This verb describes the action of a person or animal. It can also be applied to aircraft, for which see {tor:v:2}.

table.name: mem
table.column: pitch (aircraft tilts nose up or down)

This is just the verb {tor:v:1} applied to aircraft.
Pitching downwards is indicated using a negative angle (see {taH:v:2}).
The eleva"tor"s control the pitch on an airplane.

table.name: mem
table.column: Tor Books is a publisher of speculative (see {SIv:v}) fiction.

table.name: mem
table.column: Based on its usage in the {paq'batlh:src}, the thing being climbed is the object, the destination is marked with {-Daq:n}, and the starting point is marked with {-vo':n}.[2]

table.name: mem
table.column: This refers to a moment of clarity between two warriors on the field of battle.[2]

table.name: mem
table.column: [1] {DSC - Si Vis Pacem, Para Bellum:src}, [2] {Saarbrücken qepHom'a' 2019:src}

table.name: mem
table.column: to take some time to consider a matter
This idiomatic expression literally means "to chew ligament".

▶ {to'waQ yIyIv.:sen:nolink} "Take your time thinking about it." ▶ {to'waQ vIyIvtaH.:sen:nolink} "I'm in the process of taking my time considering the matter." ▶ {to'waQ yIyIvQo', DaH yIwuq!:sen:nolink} "Don't chew ligament, decide now!"

table.name: mem
table.column: This means to blink involuntarily. A slang way to say this is {mInDu' yIv:sen@@mIn:n, -Du':n, yIv:v:1}. For example, {mInDu'(wIj) vIyIv:sen@@mIn:n, -Du':n, -wIj:n, vI-:v, yIv:v:1} means "I blink".
It was stated during the Q & A session that this does not generally take an object. It is used for eyes, not lights.

table.name: mem
table.column: In comparison, {'op pIq:n@@'op:n, pIq:n} means "at some point in the future".[1]

In {Star Trek VI:src}, Chancellor Gorkon makes a toast to "the undiscovered country... the future". The phrase "The Undiscovered Country" (TUC) comes from Hamlet's soliloquy and is also the name of the film.
The example sentence {qaSDI' tuch:sen:nolink} lacks some context in the message sent to the mailing list. It was intended to translate a segment for the 50th anniversary of the German children's TV show "Die Sendung mit der Maus" about how people will live "in the future" (not at a specific point in the future, but in the future as a whole). It was proposed by {Quvar:n:name} to Dr. Okrand for that specific context. It's not a fixed expression and "in the future" might be translated in another way in some other context.

table.name: mem
table.column: to prophesize, see the future, know the future
For Klingons, to prophesize is to be able to "summon" the future somehow.
In {TOS - Mirror, Mirror:src}, Mirror Spock says to Kirk: "One man cannot summon the future."

table.name: mem
table.column: This could also be shortened to {rItwI':n@@rIt:v, -wI':v} if the context is clear.

table.name: mem
table.column: This word is listed among other militaristic terminology in the body of {KGT:src} on p.48.

table.name: mem
table.column: The temperature words really are about temperature and not about effect or perception, so that clothing, for example, is not said to be "hot" or "cold" in Klingon (but the person wearing it is).[2]
The clarification about clothing was made during the Q & A session at {qep'a' 27 (2020):src}.

table.name: mem
mem
table.column: This was used in the translation of NASA's James Webb Space Telescope Key Facts information sheet. The translation was done by the KLI.

table.name: mem
table.column: A warrior's blood boils before the fire is hot.

table.name: mem
table.column: This verb can take {'e':n:pro} as its object.[2]

table.name: mem
table.column: This can be applied to music.[2, p.71]

table.name: mem
table.column: Tung-Yen Lin was a pioneer in standardising the use of prestressed concrete.

table.name: mem
table.column:
To say "Kahlor of the House of Molor", one simply says {qeylor, molor tuq:sen:nolink} "Kahlor, House of Molor". To be more formal, one can add the father's name, as in {qeylor, qeylIn puqloD, molor tuq:sen:nolink} "Kahlor, son of Kahlin, (of the) House of Molor".[2]
Another formal and slightly archaic way to express membership in a House is to use the verb {tay':v}: ▶ {tay' qeylor molor tuq je:sen:nolink} "Kahlor is of the House of Molor" ▶ {matay' jIH molor tuq je:sen:nolink} "I am of the House of Molor" ▶ {Sutay' SoH molor tuq je:sen:nolink} "You are of the House of Molor" This construction seems to be related to the proverb {reH tay' ghot tuqDaj je.:sen}[2]

table.name: mem
table.column: See under {tuq:n} for an explanation of how to express membership in a House.

table.name: mem
table.column: This always means to remove clothes from oneself (so perhaps "doff" would be a good English translation). Without clarification, it does not indicate how much clothing is removed.[2]

table.name: mem
table.column:
This always means to put clothes on oneself (so perhaps "don" would be a good English translation). The person getting dressed is the subject, and the item of clothing is the object. To express putting clothes on someone else, use {jom:v:2}.[4]
The slang expression {qogh tuQmoHHa':sen}, literally "to take off one's belt", means "to not hear".[2]

table.name: mem
table.column: This is a device that can read the contents of a subject's brain.[2]

table.name: mem
table.column: ▶ {tera' jar Soch, DIS wa' Hut jav Hut, maSDaq SaqmeH Qu' wa'DIch HochHom turlu'taHvIS, wej logh lengwI'pu' pa'mey 'oH Apollo wa'maH wa' ra'ghom bobcho' Columbia'e'.:sen:nolink} "The Apollo 11 Command Module, 'Columbia,' was the living quarters for the three-person crew during most of the first manned lunar landing mission in July 1969."[1] ▶ {Da'Irghlu'chugh, potlhqu' Huch Daghaqbogh, 'ej yInmey lutoDlu'meH Qu' 'ut wItur 'e' QaH noblIj.:sen:nolink} "If you were bullied, money that you contribute is very important, and your gift will help us carry out an essential mission so that lives are saved."[3]
[1] {Smithsonian GO FLIGHT app:src}, [2] {Saarbrücken qepHom'a' 2016:src}, [3] {Pop Culture Hero Coalition announcement:src} ({KLI mailing list 2016.11.30:src})

table.name: mem
table.column: If the context isn't clear, {De'wI' turwI':n} would be used.

table.name: mem
table.column: From Latin "micturation", maybe also a reference to the colour of tumeric.

table.name: mem
mem
table.column:
Note that this refers to the geometric figure, and not to a glass object used for refracting light.
A prism with a three-sided base is a {ra'Duch tut:n@@ra'Duch:n, tut:n:2}, and so on. A cylinder is a {gho tut:n}.

table.name: mem
table.column: This is literally "column vehicle", and refers to the cab, not the entire system.

table.name: mem
table.column: Maltz was asked about "canon", but didn't give an answer.

table.name: mem
table.column: If you spit out liquid, then {bItuy':sen:nolink}, but if you spit out solids, then {bItlhIS:sen:nolink}.

table.name: mem
mem
table.column:
In the episode {DS9 - Blood Oath:src}, Kor asks Kang (regarding Jadzia Dax): "Why do you dismiss her like some useless t'ooho'mIrah?" This was adapted by Okrand in {KGT:src} and used in {KCD:src} (see the example sentence).[3]
The KLI got a list of vocabulary used in {KCD:src} in advance, which was printed in {HQ 5.1:src}. As this list was just a preview containing no additional information (many of the words would subsequently officially appear in {KGT:src}), {HQ 5.1:src} has been left out of the list of sources for these words. There are two minor differences with {KGT:src}, one of which was that {tu'HomI'raH:n:nolink} was simply transliterated as "T'oohomIrah" (spelled that way, but not otherwise defined or explained).[4] (See {gha'tlhIq:n} for the other one.)

table.name: mem
table.column: This is an upper-class word for {Dargh HIvje':n}. It's an archaic word which used to mean only metal cup.

table.name: mem
table.column: This is the verb {tu':v} with the suffix {-lu':v}, the combination of which is often translated as "there is" in English.[1] Note that the third-person singular prefix is used, even if the object is plural (when one might expect the prefix {lu-:v:pref}, i.e., {lutu'lu':sen:nolink}).[1; 3; 4]

table.name: mem
table.column: "Sock it to me" was a frequent catchphrase on the sketch comedy television show "Laugh-In".

table.name: mem
table.column: This can also be used for a "theme", as applied to an app.[2]
